title: Who Gen Z Is As Airline Customers
content:
Order Management Systems (OMS) are emerging as one of the few airline technologies that can actually match what Gen Z expects from digital brands: fast, transparent, mobile‑first and hyper‑personal retail experiences. By reducing the dependency on rigid PNR/ticket/EMD structures with a single order record and real‑time retail logic, OMS lets airlines behave more like e‑commerce leaders than legacy transport providers.

Who Gen Z Is As Airline Customers

Gen Z is the first fully digital‑native flying generation, and their expectations are shaped more by streaming, gaming and social apps than by traditional travel brands. They demand speed, clarity and mobile‑first design, abandoning journeys quickly when flows are slow, confusing or overloaded with friction.

Key expectations that impact airline retailing include:

  • Instant, low‑friction interactions on mobile, with minimal steps from inspiration to purchase and servicing.

  • Personalised offers that reflect their context, preferences and budget rather than generic fare ladders.

  • Transparent, “no tricks” pricing with clear breakdowns of what is included and what is extra.

  • Always‑on digital servicing: real‑time updates, self‑service changes, and control over the journey via phone.

What Modern OMS Brings To Airline Retailing

Modern airline OMS sits at the centre of an Offers & Orders architecture and coordinates offer creation, order capture, fulfillment and servicing across channels. Instead of siloed PSS, CRS, ticketing and CRM, OMS provides a single, customer‑centric order record that can be created, enriched, modified and fulfilled in real time.

Typical OMS capabilities that matter for Gen Z include:

  • Centralised orders that store every product element (flight, seats, bags, Wi‑Fi, third‑party ancillaries) in one object, independent of channel.

  • Dynamic offer creation using business rules and data to tailor bundles, prices and ancillaries at search time.

  • Real‑time event handling so that disruptions, changes and upgrades sync instantly across web, app, agent and partner channels.

  • Omnichannel APIs enabling consistent experiences across airline site, mobile app, social or partner front‑ends.

How OMS Meets Gen Z Expectations

Speed and Frictionless Journeys

Gen Z abandons flows that are slow, unstable or full of redundant steps. OMS can shorten and stabilise the end‑to‑end retail journey by:​

  • Reducing look‑to‑book complexity: a central order layer decouples modern front‑ends from legacy systems, allowing lightweight, fast UIs that call a single order API instead of multiple mainframe transactions.

  • Supporting “one‑flow” retailing from inspiration to payment: offers, order creation, payment capture and confirmation occur in a single, streamlined path rather than multiple system hops.

  • Enabling reliable post‑booking self‑service (changes, seats, ancillaries, refunds) without long call‑centre or manual processes, which aligns with Gen Z’s low tolerance for offline friction.

Personalisation and Context‑Aware Offers

Gen Z expects brands to recognise them and adapt in real time. OMS enables more intelligent airline retail by:

  • Using order context, history and business rules to assemble relevant bundles (for example, seat + bag + Wi‑Fi for a long‑haul trip, or simple no‑frills bundles for short‑haul).

  • Integrating with NDC and offer engines to support continuous pricing, micro‑segments and dynamic ancillaries tuned to willingness‑to‑pay and trip purpose.

  • Allowing consistent personalisation across channels: the same OMS‑driven logic can power airline.com, app, and partner sellers, reducing dissonance that erodes trust.

Transparency and Trustworthy Pricing

Younger travellers are sensitive to “dark patterns” and hidden fees and reward brands that are straightforward about products and costs. OMS helps airlines deliver more transparent retailing by:

  • Exposing rich product attributes (fare conditions, change/refund rules, seat and baggage details) directly in the offer and order, enabling front‑ends to show clear breakdowns.

  • Supporting NDC‑style structured content, where ancillaries and bundles are explicit elements in an offer, not bolted‑on fees, which simplifies explaining “what you get.”

  • Making order changes traceable and auditable, so customers can see exactly how price and components evolve after upgrades, disruptions or voluntary changes.

Mobile‑First, Omnichannel Control

Gen Z expects to manage the entire journey on a phone, including pre‑trip, day‑of‑travel and post‑trip interactions. OMS supports this always‑on, channel‑agnostic control by:

  • Providing APIs that allow mobile apps and third‑party experiences to create, read and modify orders without re‑entering data or switching channels.

  • Driving real‑time notifications so that schedule changes, gate updates, seat moves or service disruptions update the order and trigger push messages automatically.

  • Enabling add‑ons and services to be purchased or changed up to and during travel, in a consistent way across direct and indirect touchpoints, matching Gen Z’s preference for late, flexible decisions.

Authentic, Connected Ecosystem

Gen Z is heavily influenced by user‑generated content, peer reviews and connected services around the core trip. An OMS‑centric architecture helps airlines plug into that ecosystem by:

  • Treating non‑air products (hotels, transfers, insurance, experiences) as orderable components within the same record, enabling true “trip retailing” instead of flight‑only transactions

  • Integrating with external partners (payment wallets, loyalty marketplaces, subscription or membership schemes) via order APIs, making it easier to offer modern payment and engagement models that resonate with Gen Z.

  • Providing a data foundation for AI‑driven recommendations and service automation, which can power proactive, conversational support instead of generic call‑centre interactions.

Strategic Implications For Airlines

Industry analyses highlight that while OMS and Offers & Orders are advancing, many airlines still under‑deliver on personalisation, servicing and retail sophistication compared with what modern systems could enable. As Gen Z and Millennials come to represent the majority of air travellers, airlines that delay OMS adoption risk being locked into slow, opaque and inflexible experiences that these customers simply abandon.

For airlines, prioritising OMS is not just an IT modernisation project; it is a retail and brand strategy decision. A well‑implemented OMS allows them to:

  • Close the experience gap with digital‑native brands through faster, more personalised and transparent journeys.

  • Unlock new revenue streams via trip‑level retailing and richer ancillary portfolios tuned to Gen Z preferences.

  • Build a resilient, API‑first architecture that can evolve with future channels, devices and business models, instead of re‑engineering the stack each time customer behaviour shifts.

In short, OMS provides the structural capabilities airlines need to meet Gen Z on their own terms: instant, mobile, personalised and trustworthy airline retailing that feels far closer to the best of e‑commerce than to yesterday’s legacy booking flows
